properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Further snowfall accumulation: 5 to 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h. Locations: Churchill Falls and vicinity, and Churchill Valley. Time span: continuing until Tuesday morning. Remarks: Snow will combine with strong northwesterly winds to result in poor visibility in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve overnight tonight as winds begin to ease. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-17T10:59:51-00:00

Area: Churchill Valley, Churchill Falls and vicinity

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this evening. Snow squalls from Lake Superior continue to move through the region this evening. Additional snowfall amounts of 5 cm are possible by tonight. Snow at times heavy will make travel hazardous and visibilities reduced. Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. The snow squalls are expected to move out of the region tonight before returning tomorrow morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls from Lake Superior continue this evening and into Tuesday. Snow squalls from Lake Superior moving through the region are expected to bring additional amounts of up to 10 cm by morning. Snow at times heavy may make travel hazardous and visibilities reduced. Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. The snow squalls are expected to drift to the south of the region tomorrow afternoon and then weaken by Tuesday evening. ### Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall still possible for southwestern Nova Scotia on Tuesday night and Wednesday, less likely elsewhere. Total snowfall: possibly reaching 10 cm in the southwest, with only 2 to 5 cm now expected from Halifax eastward Locations: Atlantic coastal regions of Nova Scotia. Time span: Tuesday evening until noon Wednesday for Yarmouth County to Halifax Metro and Halifax County West. Wednesday morning to Wednesday evening for Halifax County - East of Porters Lake to Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County. Remarks: An approaching low pressure system is now expected to track further south of Nova Scotia than previously forecast on Tuesday night and Wednesday. Snow is still forecast to begin over southwestern Nova Scotia Tuesday afternoon and then spread eastward, reaching Cape Breton on Wednesday morning. However, total snowfall is now only expected to approach 10 cm over the South Shore from Yarmouth to Lunenburg Counties. Due to the uncertainty which remains in the forecast track, the snowfall forecast may be revised as the system approaches. In any case, this snowfall event has the potential to create difficult driving conditions in some areas during the Wednesday morning commute. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T19:16:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-17T03:17:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3057155714.2019
Area: Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Guysborough County, Richmond County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme wind chill values of -45 or colder are expected to occur overnight and into the morning hours for portions of northern Manitoba. These wind chill values will moderate throughout the day on Tuesday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated sea water levels are expected. Wave heights: 5 to 8 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: west-facing shorelines from Hawkes Bay to Port aux Basques. Time span: until early Tuesday morning. Next high tide: 1:30 A.M. to 3:30 A.M. Tuesday morning. Remarks: Storm surge and minor coastal flooding is possible along shorelines exposed to the west, especially near high tide tonight. Although tonight's high tide is not expected to be as high as the tide earlier this afternoon, the stronger winds and higher waves are expected to have similar impacts as experienced today. Water levels will begin to subside Tuesday morning as the tide drops. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-17T11:00:46-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A warm front and associated low pressure centre is just off Haida Gwaii and will move inland early Tuesday morning. Winds will peak tonight near 90 km/h ahead of the low pressure centre. As the low passes overnight, winds will ease and shift to westerlies of 50 km/h. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Further snowfall amounts: generally 5 cm except locally 10 to 15 cm or more over higher terrain. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 to 100 km/h. Locations: the west coast of Newfoundland. Time span: today. Remarks: While the setup for intense snow squalls is less favourable today than it was on Monday, snow and strong westerly winds continue to give blizzard conditions in many areas this morning. Conditions will slowly improve as the winds start to subside during the day today and more so tonight. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A warm front and associated low pressure centre will approach the north coast tonight. Ahead of the front, snow will intensify this evening for inland areas of the north coast. As the warm air moves onto the coast, snow will change to freezing rain at Kitimat and spread toward Terrace. Overnight, Kitimat will likely change to rain while freezing rain persists inland. At Stewart, precipitation is expected to remain as snow tonight and Tuesday morning with total snowfall amounts of 25 to 35 cm. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T15:48:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T23:49:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0660347886.2019
Area: North Coast - inland including Terrace, North Coast - inland including Kitimat, North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A Pacific frontal system will approach the BC coast tonight. The front will stall over northern Vancouver Island on Tuesday before shifting southward on Wednesday. This storm is forecast to bring widespread heavy rainfall to the west coast of Vancouver Island. For Tofino and communities further north such as Zeballos and Tahsis, heavy rain is expected for Tuesday and Tuesday night. As the front begins to move southward early Wednesday, heavy rain will start to impact communities south of Tofino. Total rainfall amounts in the range of 100 to 150 mm can be expected for this event. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T15:34:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T23:35:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3617340117.2019

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Additional snowfall: locally up to 5 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 km/h except up 100 km/h along the coast until Tuesday morning Locations: the Connaigre, Burin, and Avalon Peninsulas. Time span: tonight. Remarks: Strong westerly winds accompanying the snow squalls will produce poor visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve by Tuesday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Additional snowfall: locally up to 5 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 km/h. Locations: Green Bay - White Bay and Buchans. Time span: tonight into Tuesday. Remarks: Strong westerly winds accompanying these squalls will produce poor visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve on Tuesday. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A developing low pressure system will bring heavy snow to northern Alberta beginning Tuesday morning. Total snowfall amounts, especially near the Northwest Territories border will be 10 to 15 centimetres. Snow will taper off Tuesday overnight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
